/**
 * Core & Neck Training Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const coreNeckGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'core-neck',
  slug: 'core-neck-training',
  title: 'Core & Neck Training',
  subtitle: "The overlooked muscles that change everything",
  description: "Build a solid core for posture and a thick neck for masculine presence. Both are underrated game-changers.",
  icon: 'Target',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 8,
  order: 6,
  tags: ['core', 'neck', 'posture', 'training', 'aesthetics'],
  relatedGuides: ['training', 'v-taper', 'body-fat'],
  productIds: ['creatine_mono'],
  forumCategory: 'height-frame',
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'Why Core and Neck Matter',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Two of the most overlooked muscle groups that have outsized impact on your appearance:

**The Neck:**
A thick neck makes your head look proportionate, adds masculinity, and completely changes how you're perceived. Think about the difference between a pencil neck and a football player neck. Night and day.

**The Core:**
Beyond aesthetics, a strong core improves posture, supports lifting heavy, and defines that V-taper from waist. Weak core = weak everything else.

Most guys skip both because:
- Neck training seems weird or unsafe
- Core work is boring (crunches in the corner)
- Neither is a "mirror muscle"

This is a mistake. Both are trainable, and both pay massive dividends.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'neck-benefits',
      title: 'Neck: The Masculine Multiplier',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `A thick neck is one of the most underrated aesthetic upgrades you can make:

**Visual Benefits:**
- Head looks proportionate to body
- Jawline appears stronger
- More masculine/dominant presence
- Fills out shirt collars
- Better photos from every angle

**Functional Benefits:**
- Reduced neck pain
- Better posture support
- Injury prevention (sports, accidents)
- Improved head position for mewing

**The Reality:**
Compare a skinny neck to a thick neck on the same person. It's a completely different look. Yet almost nobody trains it.

The neck is one of the fastest-growing muscle groups because most people have never trained it. You can add an inch to your neck in 2-3 months with consistent training.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'neck-anatomy',
      title: 'Neck Muscles to Train',
      humorLevel: 'low',
      content: `Understanding what you're training helps you train it better:

**Sternocleidomastoid (SCM)**
- The muscles on the front/sides of your neck
- Creates that "thick neck" look from the front
- Trained with neck curls and lateral flexion

**Trapezius (Upper Traps)**
- The muscles connecting neck to shoulders
- Creates width and thickness from behind
- Trained with shrugs and neck extensions

**Splenius (Deep Neck Extensors)**
- Muscles on the back of the neck
- Important for head position and posture
- Trained with neck extensions

**Scalenes**
- Side of neck, often tight from desk work
- Important for balanced development
- Trained with lateral neck flexion

**Training All Directions:**
The neck moves in four directions:
1. Flexion (chin to chest)
2. Extension (looking up)
3. Lateral flexion (ear to shoulder)
4. Rotation (turning head)

Train all of them for balanced development.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'neck-exercises',
      title: 'Neck Training Exercises',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Start with bodyweight, progress to resistance:

**Beginner: Manual Resistance (First 4 Weeks)**
Use your hands to provide resistance:

1. **Neck Curls (Flexion)**
   - Push forehead against palm
   - Resist and try to bring chin to chest
   - 3x10-15 each direction

2. **Neck Extensions**
   - Cup back of head with hands
   - Resist and try to look up
   - 3x10-15

3. **Lateral Flexion**
   - Hand on side of head
   - Resist and try to touch ear to shoulder
   - 3x10-15 each side

**Intermediate: Neck Harness/Plate (After 1 Month)**
1. **Weighted Neck Curls**
   - Lie face up on bench, head off edge
   - Hold plate on forehead
   - Curl chin to chest
   - 3x15-20

2. **Weighted Neck Extensions**
   - Lie face down on bench, head off edge
   - Plate on back of head (or neck harness)
   - Extend neck up
   - 3x15-20

3. **Neck Harness Extensions**
   - Best for progressive overload
   - Start light (5-10 lbs)
   - Build to 25-45+ lbs over months

**Advanced: Neck Curls Machine**
If your gym has one (rare), use it. Best equipment for neck training.`,
      tips: [
        'Start LIGHT—the neck is sensitive and untrained',
        'Progress slowly—add 2.5-5 lbs per week max',
        'Avoid jerky movements—slow and controlled always'
      ],
      warnings: [
        'Never roll the neck under load—risk of injury',
        "Don't train to absolute failure on neck exercises",
        'Stop immediately if you feel any sharp pain'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'neck-programming',
      title: 'Neck Training Program',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's a progressive neck training protocol:

**Phase 1: Manual Resistance (Weeks 1-4)**
- Frequency: 3x per week
- Duration: 5 minutes at end of workout
- All four directions, 2 sets each

**Phase 2: Light Weight (Weeks 5-8)**
- Add 2.5-5 lb plates
- Frequency: 2-3x per week
- 2-3 sets of 15-20 reps each direction
- Focus on mind-muscle connection

**Phase 3: Progressive Overload (Weeks 9+)**
- Increase weight when you hit 25 reps easily
- Work up to 3-4 sets of 15-20 reps
- 2x per week is sufficient at this stage

**Weekly Volume:**
- 6-12 sets per week is plenty
- Don't overtrain—neck recovers but can get sore easily
- Spread across 2-3 sessions

**Sample Session (10 Minutes):**
1. Neck Curls: 3x15-20
2. Neck Extensions: 3x15-20
3. Lateral Flexion: 2x15-20 each side

Add this at the end of any workout. It doesn't take long.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'core-fundamentals',
      title: 'Core: Beyond Crunches',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your core is more than abs. It's the entire trunk stabilization system:

**Core Functions:**
1. **Anti-Extension** — Preventing back from arching (planks, ab wheel)
2. **Anti-Rotation** — Preventing torso twist (Pallof press)
3. **Anti-Lateral Flexion** — Preventing side bending (side planks, carries)
4. **Hip Flexion** — Bringing legs toward torso (leg raises)

**Why This Matters:**
Crunches only train one function (spinal flexion). A complete core routine trains all four. This builds functional strength that transfers to:
- Better posture
- Stronger lifts (squat, deadlift)
- Tighter waist appearance
- Reduced lower back pain

**The Ab Visibility Truth:**
You can do 1000 crunches but if you're at 20% body fat, you won't see your abs. Core training builds the muscle. Diet reveals it. Both are needed.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'core-exercises',
      title: 'Best Core Exercises',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Forget endless crunches. These exercises actually build a strong core:

**Anti-Extension:**
1. **Ab Wheel Rollouts** — The king of core exercises
2. **Plank Variations** — Start here if you're weak
3. **Dead Bug** — Coordination + stability

**Anti-Rotation:**
1. **Pallof Press** — Cable or band, squeeze and hold
2. **Single-Arm Carries** — Heavy dumbbell, walk straight
3. **Single-Arm Cable Rows** — Resist rotation while pulling

**Anti-Lateral Flexion:**
1. **Side Planks** — Basic but effective
2. **Suitcase Carries** — Heavy one-arm carry
3. **Copenhagen Planks** — Advanced, adductor + core

**Hip Flexion:**
1. **Hanging Leg Raises** — The best for lower abs
2. **Reverse Crunches** — Easier variation
3. **Lying Leg Raises** — Floor version

**The Vacuum:**
Not a strength exercise, but critical for waist control:
- Exhale fully
- Suck stomach in as hard as possible
- Hold 15-30 seconds
- Do daily, 5-10 reps`,
      tips: [
        'Ab wheel is brutally effective—start from knees',
        'Hanging leg raises are hard—use straps if grip fails',
        'Side planks should be felt in obliques, not hip'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'core-programming',
      title: 'Core Training Program',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Core can be trained frequently because the muscles recover fast:

**Option 1: Dedicated Core Days (2-3x/Week)**
Add 10-15 minutes of core work after upper body sessions:

- Ab Wheel Rollouts: 3x8-12
- Hanging Leg Raises: 3x10-15
- Pallof Press: 2x10-12 each side
- Side Plank: 2x30-45 sec each side

**Option 2: Integrated (Every Session)**
Add 1-2 core exercises to every workout:

- Day 1: Ab Wheel + Pallof Press
- Day 2: Leg Raises + Side Planks
- Day 3: Plank + Dead Bug
- Day 4: Repeat

**Option 3: Supersetting**
Between sets of other exercises:
- Superset Bench Press with Ab Wheel (during rest)
- Superset Squats with Dead Bug
- Efficient use of time

**Volume Guidelines:**
- 6-12 sets of direct core work per week
- Compounds (squats, deadlifts) also train core
- Don't overthink—consistency matters more than perfection

**Daily Vacuum Practice:**
- Morning, before eating: 5-10 vacuums, 15-30 sec holds
- This is cumulative—daily practice shrinks waist appearance`,
    },
    {
      id: 'obliques-warning',
      title: 'A Note on Oblique Training',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Here's something most people get wrong:

**The Goal:**
A narrow waist and visible V-taper.

**The Mistake:**
Heavy weighted oblique exercises (side bends, wood chops with heavy weight).

**The Problem:**
Your obliques are muscles. If you train them with heavy resistance, they grow. Bigger obliques = wider waist. This is the opposite of what you want.

**The Solution:**
- Skip heavy direct oblique work entirely
- Obliques get enough stimulus from:
  - Compound lifts (squats, deadlifts)
  - Anti-rotation work (Pallof press)
  - Side planks (isometric, not hypertrophy-focused)

**For Most Guys:**
Never do weighted side bends. Never do heavy wood chops. Your obliques are probably already developed enough from other training. Adding size to them will widen your waist.

**Exception:**
If you're a competitive athlete who needs rotational power (golfer, baseball player), train obliques. For aesthetics? Skip the heavy stuff.`,
      warnings: [
        'Weighted side bends can increase waist width',
        'Obliques are often overdeveloped relative to needs',
        'V-taper requires a narrow waist, not thick obliques'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's your complete core + neck upgrade plan:

**Week 1-4: Foundation**
- Neck: Manual resistance, 3x per week, 5 min each
- Core: Ab wheel + leg raises + side plank, 2x per week, 10 min each
- Vacuum: Daily, 5 holds of 20 seconds

**Week 5-8: Build**
- Neck: Add light weight (5-10 lbs), 3x per week
- Core: Progress to harder variations, add Pallof press
- Vacuum: 10 holds of 30 seconds

**Week 9+: Progress**
- Neck: Progressive overload, 2-3x per week, working toward 25+ lbs
- Core: Full routine, 2x per week, focus on getting stronger
- Vacuum: Maintenance, daily habit

**Expected Results:**
- Neck: 0.5-1 inch growth in first 2-3 months
- Core: Visible improvement in 4-6 weeks (if diet is right)
- Posture: Noticeable improvement in 2-4 weeks

**The Payoff:**
These are two of the highest-ROI muscle groups you can train. Minimal time investment, maximum visual and functional return. Don't skip them.`,
      products: ['creatine_mono'],
    },
  ],
};

1→/**
     2→ * Cardio Guide
     3→ * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
     4→ */
     5→
     6→import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';
     7→
     8→export const cardioGuide: Guide = {
     9→  id: 'cardio',
    10→  slug: 'cardio-training',
    11→  title: 'Cardio Training',
    12→  subtitle: "Not just for losing fat—but also for losing fat",
    13→  description: "Strategic cardio for fat loss, conditioning, and health without killing your gains. Find the right balance.",
    14→  icon: 'Heart',
    15→  humorLevel: 'medium',
    16→  estimatedReadTime: 8,
    17→  order: 7,
    18→  tags: ['cardio', 'fat-loss', 'conditioning', 'heart-health'],
    19→  relatedGuides: ['body-fat', 'training', 'diet'],
    20→  productIds: [],
    21→  forumCategory: 'body-composition',
    22→  heroMedia: {
    23→    id: 'cardio-hero',
    24→    type: 'image',
    25→    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1571008887538-b36bb32f4571?w=1200&q=80',
    26→    alt: 'Cardio training and running',
    27→    placement: 'hero',
    28→  },
    29→  sections: [
    30→    {
    31→      id: 'intro',
    32→      title: 'The Cardio Debate',
    33→      humorLevel: 'medium',
    34→      content: `There are two extreme camps on cardio:
    35→
    36→**Camp 1: "Cardio kills gains"**
    37→- Never steps on a treadmill
    38→- Gets winded walking up stairs
    39→- Can bench 300 but can't jog a mile
    40→
    41→**Camp 2: "Cardio is everything"**
    42→- Runs marathons
    43→- Skinny-fat physique
    44→- No muscle to show for their efforts
    45→
    46→**The Truth:**
    47→Both are wrong. Cardio is a tool. Like any tool, it's about how you use it.
    48→
    49→Used correctly, cardio:
    50→- Accelerates fat loss
    51→- Improves heart health
    52→- Increases work capacity
    53→- Enhances recovery between sets
    54→- Doesn't destroy muscle gains
    55→
    56→The key is knowing when, how much, and what type.`,
    57→      media: [
    58→        {
    59→          id: 'cardio-intro',
    60→          type: 'image',
    61→          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1538805060514-97d9cc17730c?w=800&q=80',
    62→          alt: 'Running and cardio training',
    63→          caption: 'Cardio is a tool—use it strategically',
    64→          placement: 'inline',
    65→        },
    66→      ],
    67→    },
    68→    {
    69→      id: 'fat-loss-math',
    70→      title: 'Cardio and Fat Loss: The Math',
    71→      humorLevel: 'medium',
    72→      content: `Let's get the fundamentals clear:
    73→
    74→**The Equation:**
    75→Fat Loss = Calories Out > Calories In
    76→
    77→Cardio increases "calories out." That's it. No magic.
    78→
    79→**The Numbers:**
    80→- 30 min walking (3.5 mph): ~150 calories
    81→- 30 min jogging (5 mph): ~300 calories
    82→- 30 min cycling (moderate): ~250 calories
    83→- 30 min HIIT: ~300-400 calories
    84→
    85→**The Reality Check:**
    86→A single Snickers bar is 250 calories. You'd need 30 minutes of jogging to burn that off. This is why diet is the primary lever for fat loss, not cardio.
    87→
    88→**Where Cardio Helps:**
    89→1. Creating a bigger deficit without eating less
    90→2. Allowing more food flexibility while still losing
    91→3. Breaking plateaus when diet is already dialed in
    92→4. General health benefits beyond fat loss
    93→
    94→**The Mistake:**
    95→Using cardio to "earn" food. This creates an unhealthy relationship and usually results in eating more than you burned.`,
    96→    },
    97→    {
    98→      id: 'liss',
    99→      title: 'LISS: Low Intensity Steady State',
   100→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   101→      content: `LISS is exactly what it sounds like: low intensity, sustained duration.
   102→
   103→**Examples:**

/**
 * Cardio Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const cardioGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'cardio',
  slug: 'cardio-training',
  title: 'Cardio Training',
  subtitle: "Not just for losing fat—but also for losing fat",
  description: "Strategic cardio for fat loss, conditioning, and health without killing your gains. Find the right balance.",
  icon: 'Heart',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 8,
  order: 7,
  tags: ['cardio', 'fat-loss', 'conditioning', 'heart-health'],
  relatedGuides: ['body-fat', 'training', 'diet'],
  productIds: [],
  forumCategory: 'body-composition',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'cardio-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1571008887538-b36bb32f4571?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Cardio training and running',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Cardio Debate',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `There are two extreme camps on cardio:

**Camp 1: "Cardio kills gains"**
- Never steps on a treadmill
- Gets winded walking up stairs
- Can bench 300 but can't jog a mile

**Camp 2: "Cardio is everything"**
- Runs marathons
- Skinny-fat physique
- No muscle to show for their efforts

**The Truth:**
Both are wrong. Cardio is a tool. Like any tool, it's about how you use it.

Used correctly, cardio:
- Accelerates fat loss
- Improves heart health
- Increases work capacity
- Enhances recovery between sets
- Doesn't destroy muscle gains

The key is knowing when, how much, and what type.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'cardio-intro',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1538805060514-97d9cc17730c?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Running and cardio training',
          caption: 'Cardio is a tool—use it strategically',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'fat-loss-math',
      title: 'Cardio and Fat Loss: The Math',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Let's get the fundamentals clear:

**The Equation:**
Fat Loss = Calories Out > Calories In

Cardio increases "calories out." That's it. No magic.

**The Numbers:**
- 30 min walking (3.5 mph): ~150 calories
- 30 min jogging (5 mph): ~300 calories
- 30 min cycling (moderate): ~250 calories
- 30 min HIIT: ~300-400 calories

**The Reality Check:**
A single Snickers bar is 250 calories. You'd need 30 minutes of jogging to burn that off. This is why diet is the primary lever for fat loss, not cardio.

**Where Cardio Helps:**
1. Creating a bigger deficit without eating less
2. Allowing more food flexibility while still losing
3. Breaking plateaus when diet is already dialed in
4. General health benefits beyond fat loss

**The Mistake:**
Using cardio to "earn" food. This creates an unhealthy relationship and usually results in eating more than you burned.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'liss',
      title: 'LISS: Low Intensity Steady State',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `LISS is exactly what it sounds like: low intensity, sustained duration.

**Examples:**
- Walking (incline or flat)
- Light cycling
- Elliptical at conversational pace
- Swimming easy laps

**Heart Rate Zone:**
Zone 2 cardio: 60-70% of max heart rate
(Roughly: 220 - your age = max, then multiply by 0.6-0.7)

**Benefits:**
- Minimal interference with lifting
- Easy to recover from
- Can do fasted without issues
- Burns primarily fat for fuel
- Low impact on joints
- Can do daily if needed

**Protocol:**
- Duration: 20-45 minutes
- Frequency: 2-5x per week depending on goals
- When: Morning fasted, post-workout, or separate session

**The Walking Hack:**
10,000 steps per day burns an extra 300-500 calories. This is NEAT (non-exercise activity thermogenesis) and is often more effective than formal cardio because it's sustainable and doesn't feel like "exercise."`,
      tips: [
        'Walking is underrated—10K steps/day is a game changer',
        'Incline walking burns more than flat without adding impact',
        'Can do LISS daily without recovery issues'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'liss-walking',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1476480862126-209bfaa8edc8?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Walking for cardio and fat loss',
          caption: 'Walking: The most sustainable cardio',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'hiit',
      title: 'HIIT: High Intensity Interval Training',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `HIIT alternates between intense effort and rest periods.

**Examples:**
- Sprints (track, bike, rower)
- Battle ropes
- Burpees/jump squats intervals
- Cycling sprints

**Structure:**
- 20-30 seconds max effort
- 60-90 seconds recovery
- Repeat 6-10 rounds
- Total: 15-25 minutes

**Benefits:**
- Time efficient (done in 20 minutes)
- Burns more calories per minute than LISS
- EPOC effect (elevated metabolism post-workout)
- Improves anaerobic conditioning
- More engaging than steady state

**Drawbacks:**
- Harder to recover from
- Can interfere with leg days
- Higher injury risk if form breaks down
- Not sustainable daily
- Actually requires max effort (most people don't go hard enough)

**Frequency:**
- 1-3 sessions per week max
- Not on leg day or day before
- Requires 48+ hours recovery

**The Truth About HIIT:**
Most people's "HIIT" is really "medium intensity interval training." True HIIT is incredibly demanding—you should feel like dying after the work intervals. If you can do more than 20-25 minutes, you're not going hard enough.`,
      warnings: [
        'True HIIT is brutal—most people do it wrong',
        'Limit to 2-3x/week to allow recovery',
        'Not recommended for complete beginners'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'hiit-training',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1549060279-7e168fcee0c2?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'High intensity interval training',
          caption: 'HIIT: Maximum effort, minimum time',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'liss-vs-hiit',
      title: 'LISS vs HIIT: Which Is Better?',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `The eternal debate. Here's the breakdown:

**LISS Wins When:**
- You're already doing intense lifting 4-6x/week
- Recovery is limited (sleep, stress, nutrition issues)
- Joint health is a concern
- You need daily cardio for deficit
- You're a beginner to cardio

**HIIT Wins When:**
- You're short on time
- You only need 1-2 cardio sessions per week
- Your lifting program is less demanding
- You want conditioning benefits beyond fat loss
- You're already fit and recover well

**The Optimal Approach:**
Combine both:
- 2-4x LISS per week (walking, incline, cycling)
- 1-2x HIIT per week (if recovery allows)
- Adjust based on how you feel and progress

**The Research:**
For pure fat loss, total calories burned matters most—not the type of cardio. LISS and HIIT are roughly equivalent when total calorie expenditure is matched.

Choose based on:
1. What you'll actually do consistently
2. What you can recover from
3. What fits your schedule`,
    },
    {
      id: 'preserving-muscle',
      title: 'Cardio Without Killing Gains',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `The fear of "losing gains" to cardio is overblown. But there are real considerations:

**What Actually Hurts Gains:**
1. Too much cardio volume (hours per week)
2. Running long distances (marathon training)
3. HIIT on leg days or day before
4. Cardio in a severe calorie deficit without adequate protein
5. Prioritizing cardio over lifting

**What Doesn't Hurt Gains:**
1. Walking (any amount)
2. 20-30 min LISS 3-5x/week
3. Cycling (often even complements leg training)
4. 1-2 HIIT sessions per week with recovery
5. General activity throughout the day

**The Protocol for Muscle Preservation:**
1. Lift first, cardio second (always)
2. Separate lifting and cardio by 6+ hours if possible
3. Keep HIIT away from leg training
4. Eat adequate protein (1g/lb)
5. Keep cardio modest—enough for goals, not more

**The Truth:**
Moderate cardio (3-5 hours per week) does not meaningfully impair muscle growth when nutrition and lifting are on point. The guys who lose muscle to cardio are usually:
- Doing way too much cardio
- Not eating enough
- Not lifting with enough intensity`,
    },
    {
      id: 'fasted-cardio',
      title: 'Fasted Cardio: Does It Work?',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `The idea: do cardio before eating to burn more fat.

**The Theory:**
- Glycogen is low after sleeping
- Body will use fat for fuel
- More fat burned during the session

**The Research:**
- Yes, more fat is burned DURING fasted cardio
- BUT total 24-hour fat oxidation is the same
- Your body compensates later in the day
- Overall fat loss is determined by total deficit, not timing

**When Fasted Cardio Makes Sense:**
1. You prefer it (some people have more energy fasted)
2. Scheduling (morning before work is your only option)
3. You don't like eating before exercise
4. LISS specifically (HIIT fasted can be rough)

**When It Doesn't:**
1. You feel weak or dizzy fasted
2. You're doing HIIT or intense training
3. Performance matters (fed = better performance)
4. You have blood sugar issues

**The Bottom Line:**
Fasted vs fed cardio is personal preference. Total calorie balance matters more than timing. Do whatever helps you stay consistent.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'step-count',
      title: 'The Daily Step Count Approach',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Forget formal cardio sessions. Here's a simpler approach:

**The Concept:**
Track daily steps instead of scheduled cardio. Walking is the most sustainable, lowest-impact form of movement.

**The Target:**
- Minimum: 7,000 steps/day
- Good: 10,000 steps/day
- Optimal: 12,000-15,000 steps/day

**The Math:**
- 10,000 steps ≈ 5 miles ≈ 400-500 calories
- That's 2,800-3,500 extra calories per week
- Roughly 0.5-1 lb of fat loss potential

**How to Get Steps:**
1. Walk during phone calls
2. Park farther away
3. Take stairs always
4. Walking meetings
5. Post-meal walks (also helps blood sugar)
6. Dedicated 30-45 min walk daily
7. Walking desk/treadmill desk

**Why This Works:**
- Doesn't feel like exercise
- Easy to recover from
- Fits into daily life
- Sustainable long-term
- Burns significant calories over time

**For Cutting:**
Many people find step count + lifting more sustainable than formal cardio. Walking is the secret weapon.`,
      tips: [
        'Get a step-tracking watch or use your phone',
        'Morning walks start the day with momentum',
        'Post-dinner walks improve digestion and sleep'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'programming',
      title: 'Cardio Programming by Goal',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's how to structure cardio based on your current goal:

**Goal: Fat Loss (Primary)**
- Steps: 10,000-12,000 daily
- LISS: 20-30 min, 3-4x/week
- HIIT: 1x/week optional
- Total: 3-5 hours including walking

**Goal: Maintenance/Health**
- Steps: 8,000-10,000 daily
- LISS: 20-30 min, 2-3x/week
- HIIT: 1x/week
- Total: 2-3 hours

**Goal: Building Muscle (Minimize Cardio)**
- Steps: 7,000-10,000 daily
- LISS: 15-20 min, 2x/week
- HIIT: 0-1x/week
- Total: 1-2 hours

**Goal: Athletic Performance**
- Steps: As needed
- Sport-specific conditioning
- HIIT: 2-3x/week
- LISS: Active recovery days
- Total: 3-5 hours

**Adjusting:**
- Scale slowing? Add 1 session or 2,000 steps
- Feeling overtrained? Remove HIIT first
- Recovery suffering? Reduce intensity before frequency`,
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's how to implement cardio effectively:

**Step 1: Track Current Activity**
Wear a tracker for a week. See your baseline steps and activity.

**Step 2: Set Your Target**
Based on your goal (see previous section). Start conservative and build.

**Step 3: Prioritize Walking**
Get to 10,000 steps before adding formal cardio. This is the foundation.

**Step 4: Add Formal Cardio If Needed**
Only if steps + diet isn't creating enough deficit, add:
- LISS first (2-3x/week, 20-30 min)
- HIIT second (1x/week, 15-20 min)

**Step 5: Protect Your Lifting**
- Never do cardio before lifting
- Keep HIIT away from leg days
- Eat adequately (don't stack deficit + excess cardio)

**Step 6: Adjust Based on Results**
- Losing too fast? Reduce cardio, add food
- Not losing? Add steps or one session
- Feeling exhausted? More LISS, less HIIT

**Remember:**
Cardio is a tool, not the goal. Use it strategically. More is not always better. Diet is the primary driver of fat loss—cardio is the accelerator, not the engine.`,
    },
  ],
};

1→/**

/**
 * Diet & Nutrition Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const dietGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'diet',
  slug: 'diet-nutrition',
  title: 'Diet & Nutrition',
  subtitle: "You can't out-train a bad diet",
  description: "The fundamentals of eating for aesthetics. Protein, calories, and what actually matters vs what doesn't.",
  icon: 'Utensils',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 15,
  order: 8,
  tags: ['nutrition', 'diet', 'protein', 'calories', 'macros'],
  relatedGuides: ['body-fat', 'training', 'v-taper'],
  productIds: ['food_scale', 'creatine_mono', 'omega3_fish_oil', 'collagen_peptides', 'vitamin_d3_k2', 'magnesium_glycinate'],
  forumCategory: 'body-composition',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'diet-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1490645935967-10de6ba17061?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Healthy meal prep and nutrition',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Foundation of Everything',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your physique is built in the kitchen, revealed in the gym.

You can train perfectly, but if your nutrition is garbage:
- You won't build muscle efficiently
- You won't lose fat predictably
- You'll look the same in 6 months

**The Good News:**
Nutrition is simpler than the internet makes it seem. Most of the complexity is unnecessary.

**What Actually Matters (80% of results):**
1. Total calories (energy balance)
2. Protein intake
3. Food quality (mostly)
4. Consistency

**What Barely Matters (20% optimization):**
- Meal timing
- Specific food choices within reason
- Supplement stacks beyond basics
- Nutrient timing around workouts

Let's cover the 80% first.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'diet-intro',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1498837167922-ddd27525d352?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Healthy food and nutrition',
          caption: 'Your physique is built in the kitchen',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'calories',
      title: 'Calories: The Master Variable',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Everything else is secondary to energy balance.

**The Basic Math:**
- Calories In > Calories Out = Weight Gain
- Calories In < Calories Out = Weight Loss
- Calories In = Calories Out = Maintenance

**Finding Your Maintenance:**
Method 1: Calculator estimate
- TDEE calculator gives starting point
- Typically 14-17 x bodyweight (in lbs)
- Active people higher, sedentary lower

Method 2: Track and observe
- Eat the same for 2 weeks
- Track weight daily, average weekly
- Stable = maintenance. Rising = surplus. Dropping = deficit.

**Setting Your Target:**

| Goal | Calorie Target |
|------|---------------|
| Fat Loss | Maintenance - 300-500 |
| Maintenance | TDEE |
| Lean Bulk | Maintenance + 200-300 |
| Standard Bulk | Maintenance + 400-500 |

**The Mistake:**
Going too aggressive. A 1000 calorie deficit sounds fast but leads to muscle loss, metabolic adaptation, and binges. Slow and steady wins.`,
      products: ['food_scale'],
      tips: [
        'Use a food scale for accuracy—eyeballing is notoriously wrong',
        'Track for 2-4 weeks to learn your foods, then you can estimate',
        'Weekly average matters more than daily fluctuations'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'protein',
      title: 'Protein: The King of Macros',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `If you remember one thing from this guide: hit your protein.

**Why Protein Is King:**
- Builds and preserves muscle
- Most satiating macro (keeps you full)
- Highest thermic effect (burns calories to digest)
- Hardest to store as fat

**How Much:**
- Minimum: 0.7g per pound of bodyweight
- Optimal: 0.8-1g per pound of bodyweight
- Upper limit: More than 1.2g/lb has no additional benefit

**For a 180lb Guy:**
- Minimum: 126g daily
- Optimal: 144-180g daily

**Best Protein Sources:**

| Source | Protein per 100g |
|--------|-----------------|
| Chicken breast | 31g |
| Lean beef | 26g |
| Salmon | 25g |
| Greek yogurt | 10g |
| Eggs | 13g |
| Cottage cheese | 11g |
| Whey protein | 80g |

**Hitting It Daily:**

/**
 * Skincare & Acne Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const skincareGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'skincare',
  slug: 'skincare-acne',
  title: 'Skincare & Acne',
  subtitle: "Your skin is your face. Treat it right.",
  description: "Evidence-based skincare routines for clear, healthy skin. From basics to advanced treatments like tretinoin.",
  icon: 'Droplet',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 12,
  order: 9,
  tags: ['skincare', 'acne', 'anti-aging', 'routine', 'tretinoin'],
  relatedGuides: ['maintenance', 'body-fat', 'diet'],
  productIds: [
    'cerave_cleanser',
    'cerave_moisturizer',
    'sunscreen_elta',
    'aquaphor_lip',
    'tretinoin_guide',
  ],
  forumCategory: 'poor-skin',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'skincare-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1556228720-195a672e8a03?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Clear, healthy skin and skincare',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Basics of Good Skin',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your skin is literally your face. It's the first thing people see, and it significantly impacts how attractive you appear.

**The Good News:**
- Skincare is not complicated
- Most improvements come from basics
- Results happen in weeks to months
- It's not expensive

**The Bad News:**
- Genetics play a role
- Some things take time
- There are no overnight fixes
- Consistency is required

**What Actually Works:**
1. Cleanser (clean skin)
2. Moisturizer (healthy barrier)
3. Sunscreen (prevent damage)
4. Tretinoin (for acne/anti-aging)

That's the core. Everything else is optimization.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'routine-basics',
      title: 'The Basic Routine',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Start here. Master this before adding anything else.

**Morning Routine (2 minutes):**
1. Rinse face with water (or gentle cleanser if oily)
2. Apply moisturizer
3. Apply sunscreen (non-negotiable)

**Evening Routine (3 minutes):**
1. Cleanse face (remove dirt, oil, sunscreen)
2. Apply any actives (tretinoin, etc.)
3. Apply moisturizer

**That's It.**

Don't overcomplicate. Don't buy 10 products because TikTok said so. The basic routine done consistently beats a 12-step routine done sporadically.

**Order Matters:**
Thinnest to thickest consistency:
1. Cleansers (remove)
2. Toners/serums (watery actives)
3. Treatments (tretinoin, etc.)
4. Moisturizer (seal it in)
5. Sunscreen (protect from sun)`,
      products: ['cerave_cleanser', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta'],
    },
    {
      id: 'cleansing',
      title: 'Cleansing: Do It Right',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Most guys either skip cleansing or do it wrong.

**The Goal:**
Remove dirt, oil, sweat, and sunscreen without stripping your skin.

**How to Cleanse:**
1. Wet face with lukewarm water (not hot)
2. Apply dime-sized amount of cleanser
3. Massage gently for 30-60 seconds
4. Rinse thoroughly
5. Pat dry (don't rub)

**Choosing a Cleanser:**

| Skin Type | Cleanser Type |
|-----------|---------------|
| Oily/Acne | Foaming/gel cleanser |
| Normal | Either works |
| Dry/Sensitive | Cream/hydrating cleanser |

**Recommended:** CeraVe Foaming (oily) or CeraVe Hydrating (dry)

**Common Mistakes:**
1. Over-cleansing (2x daily max)
2. Hot water (damages barrier)
3. Harsh scrubs (causes irritation)
4. Not rinsing fully (leaves residue)
5. Rubbing with towel (causes friction)

**The Feel:**
After cleansing, skin should feel clean but not tight or squeaky. If it feels stripped, your cleanser is too harsh.`,
      products: ['cerave_cleanser'],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'cleansing-technique',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1556228994-6c24d36f2d8e?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Skincare routine and cleansing',
          caption: 'Gentle circular motions for 30-60 seconds',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'moisturizing',
      title: 'Moisturizing: Seal It In',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `A healthy skin barrier is the foundation of good skin.

**Why Moisturize:**
- Prevents water loss
- Repairs barrier function
- Reduces sensitivity
- Makes skin look healthier
- Required if using actives like tretinoin

**When:**
- Morning (after cleansing, before sunscreen)
- Evening (after actives or as last step)

**Choosing a Moisturizer:**

| Skin Type | Texture |
|-----------|---------|
| Oily | Lightweight/gel moisturizer |
| Normal | Lotion texture |
| Dry | Cream texture |

**Recommended:** CeraVe PM (lightweight), CeraVe Cream (thicker)

**Key Ingredients to Look For:**
- Ceramides (barrier repair)
- Hyaluronic acid (hydration)
- Niacinamide (reduces pores, calms skin)
- Glycerin (hydration)

**Application:**
- Apply to slightly damp skin for better absorption
- Use enough to cover face without being greasy
- Don't forget neck`,
      products: ['cerave_moisturizer'],
    },
    {
      id: 'sunscreen',
      title: 'Sunscreen: The Anti-Aging Essential',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Sun damage is the biggest scam your skin is running on your future self. Block it.

**The Reality:**
- 80% of visible skin aging is from sun exposure
- UV damage accumulates over years
- By the time you see damage, it's already been happening for a decade
- Sunscreen is the #1 anti-aging product

**The Protocol:**
- SPF 30 minimum, SPF 50 preferred
- Apply every morning (yes, even cloudy days)
- Reapply every 2 hours if outdoors
- About 1/4 teaspoon for face

**Choosing Sunscreen:**

**Chemical Sunscreens:**
- Absorbs into skin, absorbs UV rays
- More cosmetically elegant
- May sting eyes or irritate some skin
- Examples: Avobenzone, oxybenzone, octinoxate

**Mineral Sunscreens:**
- Sits on skin, reflects UV rays
- Can leave white cast
- Better for sensitive skin
- Examples: Zinc oxide, titanium dioxide

**Recommended:** EltaMD UV Clear SPF 46 (best for acne-prone skin)

**The Excuses (And Why They're Wrong):**
- "I don't burn" → UV damage happens regardless
- "I'm indoors" → UVA goes through windows
- "It's cloudy" → 80% of UV penetrates clouds
- "Sunscreen causes acne" → Get a better sunscreen`,
      products: ['sunscreen_elta'],
      warnings: [
        'Skipping sunscreen will undo your other skincare efforts',
        'Reapply if outdoors for extended periods'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'sunscreen-amount',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1532413992378-f169ac26fff0?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Sunscreen and sun protection',
          caption: 'Use about 1/4 teaspoon (two finger lengths) for your face',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'acne',
      title: 'Acne: Understanding and Treating',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Acne is the most common skin concern. Here's how to actually treat it.

**What Causes Acne:**
1. Excess sebum (oil) production
2. Dead skin cells clogging pores
3. Bacteria (C. acnes)
4. Inflammation

**Types of Acne:**
- **Comedonal:** Blackheads and whiteheads (clogged pores)
- **Inflammatory:** Red, swollen pimples
- **Cystic:** Deep, painful, scarring

**Treatment Hierarchy:**

**Level 1: Basic Routine**
- Consistent cleansing
- Non-comedogenic moisturizer
- Often fixes mild acne

**Level 2: Over-the-Counter Actives**
- Benzoyl peroxide (kills bacteria)
- Salicylic acid (unclogs pores)
- Adapalene/Differin (retinoid, OTC)

**Level 3: Prescription**
- Tretinoin (see next section)
- Antibiotics (temporary)
- Spironolactone (hormonal, for women)

**Level 4: Accutane/Isotretinoin**
- Nuclear option for severe or resistant acne
- 4-6 month course, usually permanent results
- Side effects but highly effective
- Requires dermatologist

**General Rules:**
- Be patient (6-12 weeks for actives to work)
- Don't pick (causes scarring)
- Change pillowcase frequently
- Clean phone screen`,
    },
    {
      id: 'tretinoin',
      title: 'Tretinoin: The Gold Standard',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Tretinoin (prescription retinoid) is the most evidence-backed skincare ingredient for both acne and anti-aging.

**What It Does:**
- Increases cell turnover
- Unclogs pores
- Reduces acne
- Fades dark spots
- Reduces fine lines
- Improves skin texture

**How to Get It:**
- Dermatologist prescription
- Online telemedicine (Curology, Apostrophe)
- Some countries: OTC

**Starting Protocol (Critical):**

**Week 1-2:** 2x per week only
**Week 3-4:** Every other night
**Week 5-6:** Every night (if tolerated)
**Ongoing:** Nightly, thin layer

**The Retinization Period:**
Expect 4-12 weeks of:
- Dryness
- Peeling
- Redness
- Possible purging (temporary increase in acne)

This is normal. Push through carefully. It gets better.

**Application Tips:**
1. Apply to completely dry skin (wait 20 min after washing)
2. Pea-sized amount for entire face
3. Avoid eye area initially
4. Follow with moisturizer
5. Use sunscreen daily (skin is more sensitive)

**Don't Use With:**
- Benzoyl peroxide (inactivates tret)
- Vitamin C (morning only)
- Other strong actives initially

**The Payoff:**
12-month mark is where the magic happens. Consistent tretinoin use genuinely reverses aging and transforms skin.`,
      products: ['tretinoin_guide', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta'],
      warnings: [
        'Start low and slow—0.025% is enough initially',
        'Over-application causes more irritation, not faster results',
        'Tretinoin + sun exposure = damage. Always use sunscreen.'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'tretinoin-application',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1620916566398-39f1143ab7be?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Skincare product application',
          caption: 'Pea-sized amount, dot on forehead, cheeks, chin, then spread',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'tretinoin-timeline',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1598440947619-2c35fc9aa908?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Skincare progress and results',
          caption: 'Expect 3-6 months for initial improvement, 12+ for full results',
          placement: 'full-width',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'skin-type',
      title: 'Know Your Skin Type',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your skin type determines product selection.

**Oily Skin:**
- Shiny by midday
- Visible pores
- Prone to acne
- Needs: Gel cleansers, lightweight moisturizers, mattifying products

**Dry Skin:**
- Feels tight
- Flaking or rough texture
- Fine lines more visible
- Needs: Cream cleansers, rich moisturizers, hydrating ingredients

**Combination Skin:**
- Oily T-zone (forehead, nose, chin)
- Dry cheeks
- Most common type
- Needs: Balanced approach, zone-specific treatment

**Sensitive Skin:**
- Reacts easily to products
- Redness, stinging
- Needs: Fragrance-free, minimal ingredients, patch testing

**Normal Skin:**
- Balanced
- Few issues
- Needs: Basic maintenance

**How to Test:**
1. Wash face, wait 30 minutes
2. Don't apply anything
3. Observe how skin feels and looks

If shiny → oily
If tight → dry
If both → combination
If irritated → sensitive
If fine → normal`,
    },
    {
      id: 'acne-scarring',
      title: 'Acne Scars: What Actually Works',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Once acne is controlled, scars may remain. Here's what helps:

**Types of Acne Scars:**
- **Icepick:** Deep, narrow, V-shaped
- **Boxcar:** Wide, box-like depressions
- **Rolling:** Wave-like, uneven surface
- **Hyperpigmentation:** Dark marks (not true scars)

**What Actually Works:**

**For Hyperpigmentation (Dark Marks):**
- Time (fades naturally in 3-12 months)
- Tretinoin (speeds fading)
- Vitamin C (morning antioxidant)
- Niacinamide (in moisturizer)
- Sunscreen (prevents darkening)

**For True Scars (Texture):**
- Tretinoin (mild improvement over years)
- Microneedling (professional, 4-6 sessions)
- Chemical peels (professional, multiple sessions)
- Laser resurfacing (fractional CO2 or Fraxel)
- Subcision (for tethered scars)
- TCA Cross (for icepick scars)

**The Reality:**
- OTC products can't fix true textural scars
- Professional treatments are needed
- Multiple sessions required
- Results are improvement, not perfection
- Cost: $200-500+ per session

**Priority:**
1. Get acne under control first (stop creating new scars)
2. Wait for active breakouts to clear
3. Then address scarring`,
    },
    {
      id: 'lifestyle-factors',
      title: 'Lifestyle Factors for Clear Skin',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your routine matters, but so does everything else:

**Sleep:**
- 7-9 hours for skin repair
- Poor sleep = inflammation = worse skin
- Sleep on clean pillowcases (change 2x/week)
- Silk pillowcase reduces friction

**Diet:**
- High glycemic foods may worsen acne
- Dairy is problematic for some people
- Stay hydrated (not magic, but helps)
- Omega-3s (anti-inflammatory)

**Stress:**
- Cortisol triggers oil production
- Stress acne is real
- Manage what you can

**Habits:**
- Don't touch your face
- Clean your phone
- Wash pillowcases
- Don't pick at skin
- Remove makeup before bed

**Gym:**
- Sweat can clog pores
- Wipe face during workout
- Shower/cleanse after
- Don't use dirty towels on face

**Sun:**
- Some sun can temporarily help acne
- But UV damage is worse long-term
- Use sunscreen anyway`,
    },
    {
      id: 'routine-by-goal',
      title: 'Routines by Goal',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Customize based on your primary concern:

**Goal: Basic Maintenance (No Issues)**
- AM: Rinse, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, moisturize

**Goal: Acne Control**
- AM: Cleanse, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, tretinoin (or benzoyl peroxide), moisturize

**Goal: Anti-Aging**
- AM: Cleanse, vitamin C serum, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, tretinoin, moisturize

**Goal: Oily Skin Control**
- AM: Foaming cleanser, lightweight moisturizer, mattifying sunscreen
- PM: Foaming cleanser, niacinamide serum, lightweight moisturizer

**Goal: Sensitive Skin**
- AM: Water rinse, fragrance-free moisturizer, mineral sunscreen
- PM: Gentle cleanser, fragrance-free moisturizer
- Add actives very slowly

**Remember:**
Start with basics. Add one product at a time. Wait 2-4 weeks between additions. This lets you identify what works and what causes problems.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's your step-by-step skincare implementation:

**Week 1-2: Basics Only**
- Buy: Cleanser, moisturizer, sunscreen
- AM: Rinse, moisturize, sunscreen
- PM: Cleanse, moisturize
- Get consistent with this before adding anything

**Week 3-4: Assess and Adjust**
- Is skin tolerating basics well?
- Any reactions to products?
- Identify primary concern (acne, aging, etc.)

**Month 2: Add One Active**
- For acne: Start benzoyl peroxide OR tretinoin (not both)
- For aging: Start tretinoin OR vitamin C (pick one)
- Add slowly (2-3x/week first)

**Month 3-6: Build and Maintain**
- Increase frequency of actives as tolerated
- Full tretinoin use (nightly) if pursuing
- Evaluate progress monthly

**Ongoing: Consistency**
- Routine should take <5 min per session
- Results come from months/years of consistency
- Don't add new products constantly

**Product Recommendations:**
- Cleanser: CeraVe Foaming or Hydrating
- Moisturizer: CeraVe PM
- Sunscreen: EltaMD UV Clear
- Retinoid: Tretinoin 0.025% (prescription)

This is the evidence-based, no-BS approach. Simple, effective, sustainable.`,
      products: ['cerave_cleanser', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta', 'tretinoin_guide'],
    },
  ],
};

content.text:
## CRITICAL ANALYSIS: Guide Content Quality Assessment

I've completed a comprehensive review of all 9 guide files. Here are my findings:

---

## MAJOR ISSUES FOUND

### 1. **LOOKSMAXX TERMINOLOGY INCONSISTENCY - CRITICAL**

**Missing looksmaxx-specific language across ALL guides.** The guides use generic fitness/health terms instead of proper community lingo:

| Guide | Problem | Examples |
|-------|---------|----------|
| **ALL GUIDES** | Minimal use of core looksmaxx terms | No "mog" in body-fat guide, no "PSL" references in physics guides, no "softmaxx/hardmaxx" phase mentions |
